repo.description: Tree-sitter parser for Vim help files
repo.name: tree-sitter-vimdoc

body:
Problems: Header titles cannot be extracted easily (e.g., for generating a table of contents).

Solution: Expose nodes for separators (`separator`) and actual heading text (`heading`).

Closes #133

comment_data.body: I believe TS considers declaration order as part of precedence. So possibly we could avoid `prec(1,...)` by declaring these headings before `block`. But doesn't need to block this for now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -177,29 +177,31 @@ module.exports = grammar({
     // Intended for table column names per `:help help-writing`.
     // TODO: children should be $.word (plaintext), not $.atom.
     column_heading: ($) => seq(
-      field('name', seq(choice($._atom_noli, $._uppercase_words), repeat($._atom))),
+      alias(seq(choice($._atom_noli, $._uppercase_words), repeat($._atom)), $.heading),
       '~',
       token.immediate('\n'),
     ),
 
     h1: ($) =>
-      seq(
-        token.immediate(field('delimiter', /============+[\t ]*\n/)),
-        repeat1($._atom),
+      prec(1, seq(

comment_data.body:
why not call it `delimiter` since that is already the field name?
```suggestion
        alias(token.immediate(field('delimiter', /============+[\t ]*\n/)), $. delimiter),
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:

-        repeat1($._atom),
+      prec(1, seq(
+        alias(token.immediate(field('delimiter', /============+[\t ]*\n/)), $.separator),

comment_data.body: I could make it tighter, but _some_ precedence is needed to resolve the conflict between heading and possible taglinks.

comment_data.body: Good point. Do we need the field at all? This is only needed for scoping nodes (so you can capture all `(node)` that are in a specific `field`), but I don't think that's ever relevant since these are unique nodes?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: everything before the first tag is `heading` (edit: oh I see this is consistent with `h3`)? should we name it `text` and use that as the pseudo-convention for exposing the "text content" of complex captures? I was experimenting with this but only used it for "fields" (see e.g. `url`).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -177,29 +177,31 @@ module.exports = grammar({
     // Intended for table column names per `:help help-writing`.

+        alias(repeat1($._atom), $.heading),
+        optional(seq($.tag, repeat($._atom))),

comment_data.body: why was the trailing whitespace removed from the test case?
nice improvement. though i think the separator previously was just not captured, is it useful to capture it ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -205,16 +205,17 @@ EXTERNAL *netrw-externapp* {{{2
   (block
     (line
       (h1
-        (word)
-        (word)
+        (separator)
+        (heading
+          (word)
+          (word))

comment_data.body: It was not exposed, correct. I think it's useful if people want to give it a different highlight group and -- especially -- conceal (replace with proper line-drawing character).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -205,16 +205,17 @@ EXTERNAL *netrw-externapp* {{{2
   (block
     (line
       (h1
-        (word)
-        (word)
+        (separator)
+        (heading
+          (word)
+          (word))

comment_data.body: `tree-sitter test --update` did it. Since the whitespace didn't look meaningful or intended, I let it do so.
the fields were only nice to have. I personally don't use them

comment_data.body: Depends. If we use a common node (not name!) for `text` nodes (that aggregate `word`s?), then we need a field again to distinguish them.

comment_data.body: JS regex are for parsing purposes; only use literals if you want to expose them as anonymous nodes to query.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -135,14 +140,14 @@ module.exports = grammar({
       '>',
       choice(
         alias(token.immediate(/[a-z0-9]+\n/), $.language),
-        token.immediate('\n')),
+        token.immediate(/\n/)),

comment_data.body:
> I believe TS considers declaration order as part of precedence.

Only for terminals, e.g. string literals and regex patterns, and strings are higher than regex patterns by default
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: hmm... any "messiness" in the tests is usually intentional
regex has lower priority than literals (oh but that's "only for terminals")
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -135,14 +140,14 @@ module.exports = grammar({
       '>',
       choice(
         alias(token.immediate(/[a-z0-9]+\n/), $.language),
-        token.immediate('\n')),
+        token.immediate(/\n/)),

comment_data.body:
Is it in this case? Why does the test description not state that then?

(I'm happy to change this back, but only if I understand why can can prevent this from happening again.)
It's not about priority; it's what gets exposed to queries. "Hiding" stuff from queries is the primary way of keeping parser size down (and performance up).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -135,14 +140,14 @@ module.exports = grammar({
       '>',
       choice(
         alias(token.immediate(/[a-z0-9]+\n/), $.language),
-        token.immediate('\n')),
+        token.immediate(/\n/)),

comment_data.body: I don't remember. I suppose that trailing whitespace is handled by TS implicitly, so probably not important here.

> "Hiding" stuff from queries is the primary way of keeping parser size down (and performance up).

Nice. Would be useful to add that tip here: https://github.com/neovim/tree-sitter-vimdoc/blob/ce5ea848f52dfce683884a6ae2d44a0fb637ec2c/grammar.js#L2-L5

comment_data.body: I'll keep that in mind then.
Tips at home: https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/wiki/Parser-Development

> regex has lower priority than literals (oh but that's "only for terminals")

Oh, I see what you mean here. But here it's fine since the `token.immediate` takes care of it. (I tested it.)

comment_regular_data.body: @justinmk that should simplify some header handling in `gen_help_html` quite a bit (I hope).

repo.description: Tree-sitter parser for Vim help files
repo.name: tree-sitter-vimdoc

title: feat: better structured headings
